ITEM 2. DESCRIPTION OF PROPERTY.
We presently maintain our principal offices at Petroleum Towers, Suite 530 P.O. Box 52523, Lafayette, LA, 70505. Our telephone number is (337) 984-2000.
Our main manufacturing, reclamation, inspection and maintenance facility in Houston, Texas, consists of approximately 28 acres and includes a building capable of performing all inspection work in an environmentally protected area, and providing storage areas for pipe and equipment. Additional storage areas of approximately 20 acres adjoining our main operating plant are available for future expansion.
We have constructed a similar facility in Abbeville, Louisiana on property leased from the City of Abbeville for a 25 year term plus another 25 year option at the same rate beginning in 2005 with payments that began on November 1, 2008. This facility consists of a building which houses the manufacturing, reclamation, testing, engineering, storage and maintenance is expected to employ an additional 32 people. Both facilities provide excellent year-round pipe and equipment storage and maintenance services.
ITEM 3.

Question: What is the total acreage of the company's Houston facility, including both the main operational area and the additional storage space available for future expansion?

A) 28 acres
B) 20 acres
C) 48 acres
D) 32 acres

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The question requires careful reading and addition of two separate pieces of information from the text. The documentation states that the main facility in Houston "consists of approximately 28 acres" and there are "additional storage areas of approximately 20 acres adjoining our main operating plant." Adding these two figures gives a total of 48 acres (28 + 20 = 48), which corresponds to answer C. 

Answer A (28 acres) only accounts for the main facility area.
Answer B (20 acres) only accounts for the additional storage area.

ITEM 1. BUSINESS -----------------
THE PARTNERSHIP. Cable TV Fund 12-C, Ltd. (the "Partnership") is a Colorado limited partnership that was formed pursuant to the public offering of limited partnership interests in the Cable TV Fund 12 Limited Partnership Program (the "Program"), which was sponsored by Jones Intercable, Inc. (the "General Partner"). Cable TV Fund 12-A, Ltd. ("Fund 12-A"), Cable TV Fund 12-B, Ltd. ("Fund 12-B") and Cable TV Fund 12-D, Ltd. ("Fund 12-D") are the other partnerships that were formed pursuant to that Program. In 1986, the Partnership, Fund 12-B and Fund 12-D formed a general partnership known as Cable TV Fund 12-BCD Venture (the "Venture"), in which the Partnership owns a 15 percent interest, Fund 12-B owns a 9 percent interest and Fund 12-D owns a 76 percent interest. The Partnership and the Venture were formed for the purpose of acquiring and operating cable television systems.
The Partnership does not directly own any cable television systems. The Partnership's sole asset is its 15 percent interest in the Venture. The Venture owns the cable television systems serving Palmdale, Lancaster and Rancho Vista and the military installation of Edwards Air Force Base, all in California (the "Palmdale System") and Albuquerque, New Mexico (the "Albuquerque System"). See Item 2.

1.answer:

B) A 15% interest in Cable TV Fund 12-BCD Venture, which owns cable systems
C) A 76% interest in Cable TV Fund 12-BCD Venture, which owns cable systems
D) Cable television systems serving Edwards Air Force Base directly

Explanation: The question tests the understanding of the complex ownership structure described in the documentation. The correct answer is B because the document states that "The Partnership's sole asset is its 15 percent interest in the Venture." The Venture (Cable TV Fund 12-BCD Venture) is the entity that actually owns the cable television systems in the mentioned locations.

Option A is incorrect because the Partnership does not directly own any cable television systems.

Option C is incorrect because it's Fund 12-D that owns a 76% interest in the Venture, not Cable TV Fund 12-C, Ltd.

Option D is incorrect because the Partnership does not directly own any cable systems, including the one serving Edwards Air Force Base. This system is owned by the Venture, in which the Partnership only has a 15% interest.

ITEM 2. PROPERTIES
By an agreement dated February 8, 1968 among the Company and the owners of other adjacent or neighboring mining properties, the Company and the owners of the other properties entered into certain agreements, the general effect of which was to establish certain vertical boundaries between their respective properties and to waive certain existing or potential claims to extralateral rights to veins or ores found outside of the vertical boundaries of their respective properties. The Property of the Company is subject to this agreement. Pursuant to existing law, the Company is required to perform the equivalent of $100 of work each year on each of its 14 unpatented claims or to pay $100.00 per claim as a rental fee in order to maintain possessory title to such properties. These requirements are performed by Hecla Mining Company under the terms of the February 8, 1968 agreements described in Item 1 of this report. Further information regarding the Properties of the Company is set forth in this report under Item 1. Business and is incorporated herein by reference.
ITEM 3.

2.answer:

B) Perform $100 worth of work on each claim or pay $100 per claim as a rental fee
C) Establish new vertical boundaries for all adjacent properties
D) Waive all extralateral rights to veins or ores outside their property boundaries

Explanation: The documentation states that "Pursuant to existing law, the Company is required to perform the equivalent of $100 of work each year on each of its 14 unpatented claims or to pay $100.00 per claim as a rental fee in order to maintain possessory title to such properties." Option D is incorrect because although the agreement did involve waiving certain extralateral rights, this is not an annual requirement to maintain possessory title.

ITEM 2. Properties
The Partnership's properties consist primarily of leasehold interests in properties on which oil and gas wells are located. Such property interests are often subject to landowner royalties, overriding royalties and other oil and gas leasehold interests.
Fractional working interests in developmental oil and gas prospects located in the Spraberry Trend area of West Texas were acquired by the Partnership, resulting in the Partnership's participation in the drilling of 40 oil and gas wells. At December 31, 1996, 39 wells were producing with one well plugged and abandoned during 1989.
For information relating to the Partnership's estimated proved oil and gas reserves at December 31, 1996, 1995 and 1994, and changes in such quantities for the years then ended, see Note 7 of Notes to Financial Statements included in "Item 8. Financial Statements and Supplementary Data" below. Such reserves have been estimated by the engineering staff of PPUSA with a review by an independent petroleum consultant.

3.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: Which of the following statements most accurately describes the Partnership's property interests and well operations as of December 31, 1996?

A) The Partnership owned 40 producing wells in the Spraberry Trend area, with all wells actively producing oil and gas.

B) The Partnership held leasehold interests in 39 producing wells and 1 abandoned well, all located in West Texas, with reserves estimated solely by an independent petroleum consultant.

C) The Partnership participated in drilling 40 wells, resulting in 39 producing wells and 1 well plugged and abandoned in 1996, with reserves estimated by PPUSA's engineering staff.

D) The Partnership held fractional working interests in 39 producing wells in the Spraberry Trend area, with 1 well plugged and abandoned in 1989, and reserves estimated by PPUSA's engineering staff and reviewed by an independent consultant.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: Option D is correct because it accurately combines several key points from the documentation:

1. The Partnership acquired fractional working interests in developmental oil and gas prospects in the Spraberry Trend area of West Texas.
2. They participated in drilling 40 wells.
3. As of December 31, 1996, 39 wells were producing.
4. One well was plugged and abandoned during 1989 (not 1996).
5. The reserves were estimated by the engineering staff of PPUSA and reviewed by an independent petroleum consultant.

Option A is incorrect because it states all 40 wells were producing, which contradicts the information about one well being abandoned.

Option B is incorrect because it suggests the reserves were estimated solely by an independent consultant, whereas they were actually estimated by PPUSA's staff and then reviewed by an independent consultant.

Option C is incorrect because it states the well was abandoned in 1996, when it was actually abandoned in 1989.

Item 2. Properties.
We lease space for all of our Rent-A-Center Business and Mexico stores under operating leases expiring at various times through 2027. In addition, we lease space for certain support facilities under operating leases expiring at various times through 2032. Most of our store leases are five-year leases and contain renewal options for additional periods ranging from three to five years at rental rates adjusted according to agreed formulas. Store sizes average approximately 4,800 square feet. Approximately 75% of each store’s space is generally used for showroom space and 25% for offices and storage space. Our Preferred Lease kiosks occupy space without charge in the retailer's location with no lease commitment.
We believe suitable store space generally is available for lease and we would be able to relocate any of our stores or support facilities without significant difficulty should we be unable to renew a particular lease. We also expect additional space is readily available at competitive rates to open new stores or support facilities, as necessary.
Item 3.

11.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A company has two leased office spaces: the Castro Facility and the Evelyn Lease. Given the information provided, what percentage of the total leased square footage is currently subleased?

A) 28.9%
B) 37.8%
C) 45.2%
D) 52.6%

Correct Answer: B) 37.8%

Explanation:
The Castro Facility is 4,914 sq ft and has been fully subleased.
The Evelyn Lease is 45,240 sq ft, of which 14,105 sq ft has been subleased.

Total leased space: 4,914 + 45,240 = 50,154 sq ft
Total subleased space: 4,914 + 14,105 = 19,019 sq ft

Percentage of subleased space:
(19,019 / 50,154) * 100 = 37.92%, which rounds to 37.8%

This question requires careful reading of the provided information, calculation of total leased and subleased areas, and the ability to calculate percentages accurately.

B) All of NDS Group's facilities are owned, not leased.

D) NDS Group has plans to expand its presence in India.

B) is incorrect and thus the correct answer to the question. The document explicitly states "All of our facilities are leased."

D) is correct: The document states "In June 2006, we leased additional premises in Bangalore, India and expect to occupy them, once the premises have been fitted out, during the fiscal year ending June 30, 2008," indicating plans for expansion in India.

14.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A biotech company has two facilities and is subleasing portions of both. Based on the information provided, what is the approximate net annual cost of their facilities after accounting for sublease income?

A) $1,317,000
B) $3,317,000
C) $5,017,000
D) $6,717,000

Correct Answer: B

Explanation:
To calculate the net annual cost, we need to:
1. Sum up the costs for both facilities
2. Subtract the income from subleasing

For the Waltham facility:
- Annual cost: $1,079,000

For the West Coast facility:
- Annual cost: $3,938,000
- Sublease income: $1,700,000

Total costs: $1,079,000 + $3,938,000 = $5,017,000
Sublease income: $1,700,000

Net annual cost: $5,017,000 - $1,700,000 = $3,317,000

This question tests the ability to extract relevant financial information from a complex text and perform multi-step calculations to arrive at the correct answer.

Question: A multinational company is analyzing its global real estate portfolio. Based on the given data, which of the following statements is TRUE?

A) The company owns more square footage of office space internationally than it leases in the United States.
B) The total leased office space in England is larger than the combined leased office space in New Jersey.
C) The company's owned properties represent less than 15% of its total occupied square footage worldwide.
D) The largest single office location outside the United States is in Germany.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

A) Incorrect. The company owns 174,000 sq ft internationally (70,000 in England + 104,000 in Germany), while leasing 924,000 sq ft in the US (401,000 + 185,000 + 123,000 + 29,000 + 26,000 + 52,000 + 58,000 + 22,000 + 13,000 + 15,000).

B) Incorrect. The total leased office space in England is 377,000 sq ft (297,000 + 80,000), while the combined leased office space in New Jersey is 586,000 sq ft (401,000 + 185,000).

C) Correct. The total occupied space is 1,691,000 sq ft. Owned properties consist of 174,000 sq ft (70,000 in England + 104,000 in Germany), which is about 10.3% of the total, less than 15%.

D) Incorrect. The largest single office location outside the US is the 297,000 sq ft leased warehouse in England, not the 104,000 sq ft owned office in Germany.

33.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A company owned 659 twenty-foot, 279 forty-foot, and 403 forty-foot high-cube marine dry cargo containers as of December 31, 2003. During 2003, they disposed of 131 twenty-foot, 54 forty-foot, and 103 forty-foot high-cube containers. What percentage of their total container inventory (by count, not volume) did they dispose of in 2003?

A) 15.3%
B) 21.4%
C) 18.7%
D) 13.9%

Correct Answer: B) 21.4%

Explanation: 
To solve this, we need to:
1. Calculate the total number of containers before disposal
2. Calculate the total number of containers disposed
3. Divide the disposed containers by the total and multiply by 100

Total containers before disposal:
659 + 279 + 403 = 1,341

Total containers disposed:
131 + 54 + 103 = 288

Percentage calculation:
(288 / 1,341) * 100 = 21.4%

This question tests the ability to extract relevant information from a complex text, perform multi-step calculations, and calculate percentages accurately.

52.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A company is planning to move into a new office space. Based on the information provided, what is the approximate annual rent per square foot for the new building, assuming no adjustments?

A) $8.70
B) $17.40
C) $21.60
D) $34.80

Correct Answer: B

Explanation:
The question requires careful analysis of the given information and some calculations:

1. The new building is 50,000 square feet.
2. The monthly rent is $72,500.
3. To calculate the annual rent per square foot:
   - Annual rent: $72,500 * 12 = $870,000
   - Per square foot: $870,000 / 50,000 = $17.40

A) $8.70 is incorrect. This would be the result if the given rent were for 6 months instead of 1 month.
B) $17.40 is correct. This is the annual rent per square foot based on the given information.
C) $21.60 is incorrect. This might result from a calculation error or misinterpretation of the data.
D) $34.80 is incorrect. This is double the correct amount and might result from calculating based on 24 months instead of 12.

The question tests the ability to extract relevant information from a complex text, perform multi-step calculations, and arrive at the correct conclusion. It also requires understanding of real estate terminology and basic financial concepts.

The PUMA Program was established pursuant to a trust deed (the “Trust Deed”), dated July 13, 1990. The Trust Deed provides the general terms and structure for securitization under the PUMA Program. A sub-fund notice (the “Sub-Fund Notice”) from Macquarie Securitisation Limited, as the manager of the PUMA Program (the “Manager”), to Perpetual Trustees Australia Limited, as issuer trustee (the “Issuer Trustee”), sets out the specific details of each PUMA Global Trust. PUMA Global Trust No. 3 (the “Trust”) issued the Class A Mortgage Backed Floating Rate Notes (the “G-3 Notes”) pursuant to a Note Trust Deed dated as of January 20, 2003 (the “Note Trust Deed”), between the Issuer Trustee, the Manager and the Note Trustee. For further information, refer to the Prospectus dated January 20, 2003 (the “Prospectus”). Capitalized terms used in this Form 10-K and not defined have the same meanings given to them in the Prospectus.
The only business of the Trust is the collection and distribution of payments on the residential mortgage loans and the acquisition of housing loans in the manner described in the related Prospectus. Accordingly, there is no relevant information to report in response to Item 101 of Regulation S-K.

The Company’s headquarters are located in Lake Forest, California, where the Company leases a 51,000 square foot building. The Company entered the lease in 1997 and it has a term of 10 years. Question: A company leases office, manufacturing, and warehouse space in Troy, Michigan. Based on the information provided, what is the approximate net monthly cost of the lease to the company after considering sublease income?

A) $12,000
B) $14,700
C) $17,400
D) $12,700

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The document states that the minimum monthly lease payment for the extended term is approximately $14,700. However, it also mentions that the company has subleased a portion of its warehouse space for $2,700 per month. To calculate the net monthly cost, we need to subtract the sublease income from the total lease payment:

$14,700 - $2,700 = $12,000

Therefore, the approximate net monthly cost of the lease to the company is $12,000.
